item.title: Must We Mean What We Say
item.description: Author Main question: does what we ordinarily say/mean have a direct+deep control over what we can philosophically say/mean? Goal: respond to objections to the methodology of ‘ordinary language philosophy’ (by Mates) Distinguish 3 kinds of statements about ordinary language * Statements which produce instances of what is said in a language “We do say … but we don’t say …” “We ask whether … but we don’t ask whether …” Like above, but with explications “When we say …, we imply/suggest/say …” “We don’t say … unless we mean …” Generalizations, tested by reference to the first two types Working example: disagreement between Austin and Ryle * Austin: “We say ‘The gift was made voluntarily’ " (type 1) Ryle: “It makes sense… to ask whether a boy was responsible for breaking a window, but not whether he was responsible for finishing his homework in good time” (type 1) Ryle: “‘voluntary’/‘involuntary’ are applied as adjectives to actions which ought not be done” (type 3) Praise of Ryle’s generalization: Philosophical use of “voluntary” is distinct/disconnected from “volition” People think confusedly as if everything is either appropriately described as voluntary or involuntary Criticism of Ryle’s generalization: Saying there must be something morally fishy about the action that is described as voluntary is not general enough.

item.title: What the Tortoise said to Achilles
item.description: Written by Lewis Caroll in 1895. [-@carroll2021tortoise] Summary The Tortoise assumes a proposition $p$ and a material conditional $p \implies q$.

item.title: 02 - Inference and Meaning and Language Games (2009)
item.description: Author Prev Next Note on Sellars’ style He preferered the ‘Mystery story’ style: There’s a problem, and many competing potential explanations These explanations engage each other dialectically Only at the end would you learn the philosopher’s actual position In contrast to the ‘Journalistic’ style: Tell them what you’re going to tell them Tell them Tell them what you told them Material inferences Let an inference be a statement with a material conditional, i.

item.title: 02 - Rorty’s Critique of Enlightenment Representationalism and Analytic Philosophy
item.description: Author Prev Next A discussion of Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature. Brandom views the core argument to be chapter 4, which this lecture focuses on.

item.title: 03 - Language as thought and different species of ought (2009)
item.description: Author Prev Next Language as thought and communication Sellars wants to give us a naturalistic account of intentionality. Logical behaviorism / philosophical behaviorism

item.title: 03 - Rorty Finds His Pragmatist Voice
item.description: Author Prev Next Major lessons (From the discussion of truth as “what is best in the way of belief” as opposed to correspondence with reality): How the combination of: declarativism blurring out all distinctions of kind of claimable expressivism a local expressivism about what one is doing in attributing truth — namely not describing the claimable, but endorsing it underwriting a global antirepresentationalism because of special properties of the vocabulary of truth together underwrite a Jamesean understanding of truth-talk.

item.title: 04 - Counterfactuals and the Kant-Sellars Thesis (2009)
item.description: Author Prev Counterfactuals and dispositions Uses Principia Mathematica notation, which takes some time to learn. Goodman has let the formalism of classical extensional logic mislead him in thinking about counterfactuals.

item.title: 10. Goodness
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Two notions of good Distinction: good (absolutely) vs good for something vs good E.g. It’s good to be kind, it’s good for me to study math, that’s a good car British 20th centurary moral philosophers like GE Moore don’t like “good for X” wanting a morality that is not egoistic, instead trying to frame in terms of absolute good.

item.title: 11. Philosophical pictures
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Augustinian picture of how we learn language Wittgenstein opens PI Augustine’s picture: Common sense description: words name objects, sentences are combinations of such names Every word has a correlated meaning which is the object for which the word stands.

item.title: 12. Contextualism
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Contexualism concerns the truth of an utterance of depending on factors outside of the statement itself. There is a spectrum of statements one can acknowledge as contexual: At one extreme, statements like “I am cold” The truth is obviously contexually dependent on the speaker of the utterance.

item.title: 13. Judgment aggregation
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What is it? A formal theory characterizing various ways to combine individual beliefs into collective beliefs What could it mean for a group to have beliefs over and above the beliefs of the individuals?

item.title: 15. Religious toleration
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Why tolerate religion? Why protect religious conscience, over and above other forms of moral conscience? Historically, lots of religious intolerance have led to atrocities.

item.title: 16. Justice
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Rawls’ political philosophy “Completing” the contract theory of justice started by Hobbes, developed by Locke / Rousseau / Kant.

item.title: 17. Mechanism and causation
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Action at a distance Action at a distance E.g. Gravity/EM, something in one place can affect something far away without anything passing in between Example Trying to explain how a magic trick (making a match levitate) works.

item.title: 18. Language and power
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next This concerns the pragmatics of language Social identities are skills, being a professor/parent is like dribbling a basketball “Calls” Say “Yo, Matt!

item.title: 19. Epistemic vigilance
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Information given to us via testimony vs sense experience There are many situations where we trust and others where we distrust Need to be able to benefit from communication with others.

item.title: 2. Poetry
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What do we mean by poetry Clarification: “poetry” to Plato is more similar to what we call theatre (performative context).

item.title: 20. Faith
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Belief when you don’t have overwhelming evidence. Something distinct from knowledge. E.g. Faith in the goodness of humanity.

item.title: 21. Political liberalism
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What does “liberalism” refer to? Used in such a wide variety of senses that it means almost nothing at all now.

item.title: 22. Collective action
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Can a group of people do an action? We regularly conjoin plural subjects with action verbs. We have a desire to analyze the collective action purely into terms of the individual actions.

item.title: 23. Transcendental arguments
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next “How possible” questions General form: X makes Y seem impossible, yet nevertheless Y is possible. Can’t we just reject X because we take Y to be possible, which contradicts taking X seriously?

item.title: 24. Perception of music
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Is hearing emotion in music a purely cultural convention? Distinguish two questions Whether culture has impact on the perceptual states from hearing pieces of music Whether on a particular occasion of hearing music, the perception depends on cultural factors.

item.title: 25. Coversational context
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What does “conversational context” mean? The situation in which a discourse takes place. Not just surrounding material but also the attitudes of the speakers, their interests, the point of what they’re trying to say, etc.

item.title: 26. Evolutionary ethics
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What is altruism? “pure altruism” Help to someone else at some cost to self (distinct from reciprocal altruism: done with expectation of return) Was the tendency to behave altrusitically evolved?

item.title: 3. Nietzsche and Morality
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What does Nietzsche mean by morality? Nietzsche means something different from ethics when using the term morality

item.title: 34. Moral disagreement
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Moral realism - moral claims are objectively true or false Morals are objects of belief (things out there) E.

item.title: 4. Sexuality and Law
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next There has been historical precedent to place legal restrictions on human behavior due to disgust reaction

item.title: 45. Probability
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Conflict between epistemic and objective notions of probability In the former, to express a claim about a coin toss having a 50% chance of being heads is to make a claim about a rational being’s own knowledge, among other things.

item.title: 5. Perception
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What is interesting about perception for philosophers (distinct from biologists/neuroscientists)? Perception has necessary role within analysis of certain concepts Philophers need not come up with a theory of perception Empirical facts about perception may be useful, and the physical theories of perception need not be challenged E.

item.title: 6. Experimental philosophy
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What is it? It’s an alternative source of evidence towards philosophical theses. It’s not always meant to undermine traditional (armchair / mathematical) philosophy.

item.title: 7. Nature and ethics
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Naive way of incorporating the two Something is not acceptable because it is ’not natural'. This has counterexamples in both dimensions (good things - e.

item.title: 8. Evolutionary psychology
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next What do they study Study of traits shaped by natural selection No formal distinction from evolutionary biology Example psychological traits/behaviors: jealousy, homicide, male promiscuity What was its evolutionary function of jealousy?

item.title: 9. Metaphor
item.description: Elucidations: Prev Next Examples of Metaphor What are examples of metaphor? Need to be careful to not use ‘dead metaphors’ idioms “bit the dust” / “went west” / “bought the farm” -> die Metaphors are devices for saying something and using something else Questions philosophers ask There are two lines of questions: Technical ones in the philosophy of language (e.

item.title: Behaviorism
item.description: This is related to the problem of: suppose you follow a rule. You use a representation of that rule to train the next generation to follow the rule.

item.title: Bradley's Problem
item.description: Original argument appearring in Chapters II and III of [-@bradley2016appearance}] (originally 1893). Bradley notes that there appears to be such a thing as ‘a lump of sugar’, and this thing appears to have qualities such as whiteness, sweetness, and hardness.

item.title: Instrumentalism
item.description: All of our evidence in science comes from empirical observation, so all of our concepts (and claims) must be translatable without remainder into observational vocabulary.

item.title: Kant-Sellars thesis
item.description: From three premises: what you need to move from Labeling to describing is situation in a space of implications space of implications must draw lines between implications that will between counterfactual circumstances under which the implication would still be good, and those in which wouldn’t the expressive job, not in the first instance, a descriptive job that’s characteristic of modal vocabulary is to make explicit those range those implications and those ranges of counterfactual robustness Put another way, suppose Sellars is right that modal expressions function as inference licenses.

item.title: Meaning and truth
item.description: Alfred Tarski’s theory of truth says: if you take meanings for granted, I can give you a truth predicate.

item.title: Noumena and phenomena
item.description: In the eyes of Hegel/Sellars/Brandom, Kant is interpreted as having radicalized the distinction between: primary qualities (properties that are truly there) secondary qualities (properties that are due to us).

item.title: Objective and subjective facts
item.description: So, a second characterization of pragmatism might go like this: there is no epistemological difference between truth about what ought to be and truth about what is, nor any metaphysical difference between facts and values, nor any methodological difference between morality and science.

item.title: Ontological and deontological matters
item.description: Ordinarily we think of the ontological and the deontological as being very different, easily distinguishable kinds of things. However, Sellars’ quote

item.title: Ought to be vs ought to do
item.description: Ought to do’s Ought to be’s Rule of action Rule of reflection If you’re in circumstances $C$, do $A$ Pattern based judgment Conceptually articulated Not necessarily conceptually articulated Rules of deliberation Rule of assessment/criticism First personal Third personal judgment of some behavior What’s appropriate for me to do?

item.title: Sense data and concepts
item.description: It feels natural to try to reduce concepts to combinations of sense impressions (this is what Locke/Hume do). This is a mistake that comes from the fact that sense impressions are causally prior to our concepts.

item.title: The Frege-Geach problem
item.description: A problem for people who subscribe to emotivism. Sets a critirion of adequacy for them. Also sometimes called the embedding problem.
